child.pub-comments: According to Tryon 1973, North-Central New Hebrides Group contains 98 languages, spread across 6 subgroups. “This subgroup is by far the largest subgroup within the New Hebrides, and appears to include all of the languages of the Banks and Torres Islands, together with those of Maewo, Aoba, north and central Pentecose and probably all the languages of Santo with the exception of the languages of the northeast of that island, which belong to the East Santo Group” (Tryon 1973:309). “While the languages assigned to the North-Central New Hebrides Group present certain problems in the subgrouping, there appears little doubt that they all belong to the suggested New Hebrides 'Family'” (Tryon 1973:310).
According to Tryon 1973, North New Hebrides has 53 languages.

child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1973. Linguistic Subgrouping in the New Hebrides: A Preliminary Approach, Oceanic Linguistics, No. 1/2 edn., vol. 12, 303-351.

child.pub-comments: According to Tryon 1973, Epi has 6 languages, of which Lewo is representative. “In terms of morphological features, especially consonant alternation, the Epi subgroup appears most closely related to the Efate subgroup, although in terms of lexicostatistics the two subgroups cannot be said to be in close relationships” (Tryon 1973:310).

child.pub-comments: According to Tryon 1973, North Malekula has 12 languages. “The languages of north Malekula appear to form a subgroup apart from the rest of the island. In fact, on purely lexico-statistical grounds they might even be considered to constitute a separate group” (Tryon 1973:309).

child.pub-comments: According to Tryon 1973, Erromanga Group has 2 languages, of which Sie is representative. “The three southern groups, Erromanga, Tanna and Aneityum, are also on the borderline of 'Family' membership. […] These southern languages have long been considered abberant by most writers” (Tryon 1973:310).

child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1973. Linguistic Subgrouping in the New Hebrides: A Preliminary Approach, Oceanic Linguistics, No. 1/2 edn., vol. 12, 303-351.

child.tree-val: New Hebrides, subtree of Austronesian: Tryon 1973

child.pub-comments: According to Tryon 1973, Aneityum Group has only one language. “The three southern groups, Erromanga, Tanna and Aneityum, are also on the borderline of 'Family' membership. […] These southern languages have long been considered abberant by most writers” (Tryon 1973:310).

child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1973. Linguistic Subgrouping in the New Hebrides: A Preliminary Approach, Oceanic Linguistics, No. 1/2 edn., vol. 12, 303-351.

child.tree-val: New Hebrides, subtree of Austronesian: Tryon 1973

child.pub-comments: According to Tryon 1973, East Santo Group contains 6 languages, of which Sakau is representative. “The most problematic [group], perhaps, is the East Santo Group, whose represenative, Sakau, shares only 15 percent common cognates with the representative of the Tanna Group. The East Santo Group is, however, retained provisionally with the 'Family', as Sakau shares considerably more than 15 percent common cognates with the languages in the northern New Hebrides, together with certain morphological features” (Tryon 1973:310).
child.geography: Spoken in east and northeast Santo Island.

child.publications: Tryon, Darrell T. 1973. Linguistic Subgrouping in the New Hebrides: A Preliminary Approach, Oceanic Linguistics, No. 1/2 edn., vol. 12, 303-351.
child.tree-val: New Hebrides, subtree of Austronesian: Tryon 1973

child.tree-val: New Hebrides, subtree of Austronesian: Tryon 1973

child.pub-comments: According to Tryon 1973, Tanna Group has 5 languages, of which Lenakel is representative. “The three southern groups, Erromanga, Tanna and Aneityum, are also on the borderline of 'Family' membership. […] These southern languages have long been considered abberant by most writers” (Tryon 1973:310).
